question.title: Trying to print a 2D array where every odd number is random
question.body:
I'm writing a method that creates a 2d array and if the index of the column is odd (ex: arr2d[a][b] where b is odd), the value of that spot is a random integer between 90 and 100.

Every time I print the array through a for loop, it returns 0 as the value for every index. Even when I only print one spot specifically instead of the whole array, it still returns as zero.

No errors show up in the terminal at all.

Here is my code:

static public int[][] createTransitionArray(int row, int col)
{
    int[][] arr2d = new int[row][col];
    
    int zero = 0;
    
    for (int i = row; i == 0; i--)
    {
        for (int j = col; j == 0; j--)
        {    
            int randomInt = (90 + (int)(Math.random() * ((100 - 90) + 1)));

            if (j % 2 == 0)
            {
                arr2d[i][j] = zero;
            }
            else if (j % 2 != 0)
            {
                arr2d[i][j] = randomInt;
            }
        }   
    }
    System.out.println(arr2d[2][3]);
    System.out.println(arr2d[4][5]);

    for (int k = 0; k < row; k++)
    {
        for (int l = 0; l <col; l++)
        {
            System.out.print(arr2d[k][l]);
        }
        System.out.println("");
    }
    return arr2d;
}

Current output:

0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000
0000000000

Expected output (non-zero numbers are random between 90 and 100)(ignore lines):

|0|99|0|94|0|100|0|93|0|99
|0|100|0|93|0|96|0|99|0|96
|0|93|0|94|0|91|0|93|0|97
---------------------------

---------------------------
|0|96|0|100|0|91|0|97|0|94
---------------------------
|0|100|0|94|0|99|0|93|0|99
---------------------------
|0|93|0|100|0|97|0|95|0|95
---------------------------
|0|92|0|93|0|91|0|100|0|100
---------------------------
|0|95|0|95|0|96|0|98|0|95
---------------------------
|0|99|0|100|0|97|0|98|0|93
---------------------------

(sorry for the formatting, I'm new, I don't know why it's bold)

answers.body:
The main problem is that the for is written wrong, you set as a condition that i (and j) is equal to 0 but that's exactly why you never enter the cycle

Try to modify this:

for (int i = row; i == 0; i--)
    {
        for (int j = col; j == 0; j--)
        {    
             ...
        }
}

with this:

for (int i = 0; i < row; i++)
        {
            for (int j = 0; j <col; j++)
            {    
                ...
            }   
        }

Let's check your code:

When you instantiate an array of integers as follows:

int arr2d[][] = new int[ row ][ col ];

Java, initializes all the items of the same with the value “0”, so we dispense with the variable “zero” and the corresponding “if”.

Let's look at the for statements:

for( int i = row; i == 0; i-- ) {
    for( int j = col; j == 0; j-- ) {

The conditions of both for are wrong, they will only iterate when “i” and “j” are equal to “0” (i == 0, j == 0) and as both are instantiated with a value other than “0”, the for code is never executed.

Obtaining the random number:

First of all, it doesn't make sense to get a random number when I'm not going to use it, so we move that portion of the code into the if.

int randomInt = (90 + (int)(Math.random() * ((100 - 90) + 1)));

On the other hand, we can simplify it by using:

int randomInt = 90 + (int) ( Math.random() * 11 );

And to finish, I would put the code that prints, in a new method:

static public int[][] createTransitionArray( int row, int col ) {
   int[][] arr2d = new int[ row ][ col ];
   for( int i = row - 1; i > 0; i -- ) {
      for( int j = col - 1; j > 0; j -- ) {
         int randomInt = 91 + (int) ( Math.random() * 11 );
         if( j % 2 != 0 ) {
            arr2d[ i ][ j ] = randomInt;
         }
      }
   }
   return arr2d;
}

void show( int matrix[][] ) {
   for( int i = 0; i < matrix.length; i ++ ) {
      for( int j = 0; j < matrix[ i ].length; j ++ ) {
         System.out.print( matrix[ i ][ j ] );
      }
      System.out.println( "" );
   }
}

question_comments.body: Use code block format for the outputs and errors, same as for source code.

Try running your code in a debugger. A debugger allows you to run your code one-line-at-a-time while allowing inspection of values of variables at each step. "Using a debugger is an expected basic skill.". You may need a refresher lesson on Java's for loops.
